men's jackets. So you said you were promoted, did this mean more money? Yes, they had more money then as well.
Do you remember how much you had? I think my wages went up to £6 eventually, yes, yes, which was quite a lot really, you know, just good.
And I could save a bit then to get married, you know, so yeah, that was okay. And can you describe the FAF machine, because I've heard about these FAF machines.
Well, it was quite a tall machine and it had, when the needle came down onto the end underneath, it was on like a pillar, the end underneath was, it wasn't a flat surface at all, it was risen, you know.
And we had to put the whole sleeve over that and then it would, you know, tack it in and then you'd have to sew it in afterwards.
But I thought it was quite special because this machine was, it had cost a lot of money and they'd brought it onto the shop floor and I was on my own.
I wasn't on a conveyor belt anymore. I was, I had the machine on the side, you know, and I was handling then the whole of the jacket.
I was handling the whole thing, you know, not just the main little product, it was the whole product.
And then of course, I was a retropancery for every so many that you did. So if I was in front of myself, I could nip upstairs then, you know, I could have a break, you know.
So these FAF machines, I mean, how many of them were in the factory?
Oh, there weren't many. I think I was one of the first to have one. And I think from there, plus they may have had a few more after that.
But of course, there were different sorts of machines, there was all sorts of machines, overlocking and they were all industrial, big and fast, fast, very fast machines.
Did that make you feel quite special?
Yes, very, because I was sitting on my own like a thronger and I wasn't on the conveyor belt anymore. So it was good.
What about speaking? Could you talk when you were on the conveyor belt?
Yes, to the person opposite.
So did you mind sort of not, or could you still talk when you were on the machine?
Well, I could, yes, but it wasn't so convenient and maybe that was better really because I was getting on with it better, you know.
You said there was music playing. Do you remember? Was it the radio or was it records?
No, it was the radio and I think it was workers play time, yes. And the people used to send requests and different things.
And we all had our favourites of course. And what we'd do was, if my friend was working down the other end of the factory and a record would come on that we liked, or music,
we'd both hold our hands up and wave to each other, you know, which is so special to us.
But we thought it was wonderful, you know, they're playing our music, you know. It was good.
Did you use to request songs for people? Or just say, I want this to be played?
Well, I never did personally, but some people did obviously, yes. I didn't though. If it came on and we liked it, that was it, you know.
Do you remember what the songs were?
Oh gosh, oh gosh, it was, I know Frank Sinatra was one of my favourites. And I think there was Billy Eckstein then, and Matt Monroe.
Wasn't with Matt Monroe then? No, Knacking Cole, that's the one. Oh, there was lots, and of course, Jerry Lee Lewis, and it was, oh god, I can't remember all of them,
because Rock and Roll had started to come in then, and it was Bill Haley and the Comets, and yes, and Elvis of course, and that was the age of the Rock and Roll, you know. So we loved that.
So did you all use to sing as well? Yes, oh yes, all the time. Yeah, all the time.
Do you know how many people worked in the factory when you were there?
I would say roughly, oh, got to be about, oh, over a thousand, 1,500 maybe more even. Easily, easily. Mostly girls, because the men had the manual jobs, but all the machines were run all by girls, all by women.
There were no men on the machines then, in those days. It was all women.
And so it was mostly women, was it? Yes. And you said the men did the cutting and the?
The cutting, and they were usually in the dispatches, and some were on pressers, the big pressers, which pressed the trousers and things, because they were big, heavy pressers.
There were few women on the presses as well, but mostly the men did it, because they were quite manual, you know, to handle.
But I never seen a man on his own machine there when I worked there. Only the mechanics, where they used to come and repair the machines, you know.
What was the relationship between the women and the men? Good, very good. Oh, excellent, because we had fun, you know.
And it was good, clean fun. If they knew you were getting married, which was in my case, the girls on your convey about all, on your section, would vacuum your hair,
put all sugar soap in it, which is what they used for doing certain things, and all the chalk that they used for marking out the materials,
scrape it all into your hair, and put you in a truck and roll you down into the men's department and leave you there, so that you couldn't get out.
But the men used to help you out, and they'd get you back to your machine, you know. But, oh, it was good. It was a good relationship with the men and the women, I thought. Really good.
We all got on wonderful. Well, that's where I met my husband. Was there any harassment, you know, either way?
We used to have little things like happening. We used to get a smell every now and again, and we'd say, we did have a lot of rats there, because there was a bedding department as well,
and the rats used to get into the bedding, and if we'd, this smell would take us over, we'd say, all out, all out, and we'd all walk out the canteen, because we were in the union then.
And we'd stay out there until they'd sorted it, you know. And we did also have a plague of blackpats. I don't know if you ever know what they're like, but they're like cockroaches,
and they would get in your bag, and they'd be in the material, they'd go into the material, because they liked the warm, you know, of the material. And, oh, when you came across them, it was horrible, horrible.
I've even carried some home with me. We used to have a bucket bag, we used to call them bucket bags then, like a handbag we'd call it now, and I remember going home, and my lunch was still left in my bag,
and when I went into Richard to take it out, there was these blackpats, and they all came out of my bag. Oh, and I was screaming, and this was at home now, so I carried them all away from the factory, all the way home on the bus as well.
So, but that was, they couldn't get rid of them, obviously, they did try. It was just because they were attracted to the warmth of the material, because we sewed a lot of Harris tweed and all that sort of thing, you know. Probably came in with the material, I expect.
